sect2.title: installing from develepment source tree
sect2.para: The project bluefish is hosted by SourceForge.net http://sourceforge.net. For more information read the documentation there. The project homepage is http://sourceforge.net/projects/bluefish. For managing the changes of the devolopers, a version controll system ist installed. If you still nothing heared about cvs, check the CVS-Book of Karl Fogel http://cvsbook.red-bean.com/cvsbook.html. To the cvs repository, where the bluefish sources are, everyone have access to read them.

The sources can be checked out through anonymous (pserver) CVS with the following instruction set. The module you wish to check out must be specified as the modulename. For the bluefish gtk2 version, it's bluefish-gtk2.

First, you have to login: cvs -d :pserver:anonymous@cvs.bluefish.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/bluefish login When prompted for a password for anonymous, simply press the Enter key. and second, check out the module: cvs -z3 -d :pserver:anonymous@cvs.bluefish.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/bluefish co bluefish-gtk2 Now, the sources are in the subdir bluefish-gtk2 of your current directory.

If you want to take the actual version of the blufish sources, you can simply make an update. You have to go in the subdir bluefish-gtk2 and type cvs update. If you have an modem or isdn internet access please have some patient.
The next step is to create the configure script. Execute autoconf to do that.
If you have already compiled bluefish, run make clean to remove the compiled binaries and objects.
Now, it's quite simple, like every open source software. You have to run make to compile it. After that put the binaries and ressources to the place, where they were found: type make install.

sect1.title: installing a bluefish binary distribution
sect1.para: For Debian users this is very simple. Just run the command "apt-get install bluefish" and bluefish will be downloaded, installed and configured.

For rpm based distributions, first check if your distribution does have a recent Bluefish version. If it does not, download the rpm for your distribution from any of the bluefish mirrors. to be finished......

sect1.para: The first time you run bluefish it will create a directory ~/.bluefish where all configuration is stored.
